description.text:
These models show some properties of chemical elements. update 2016/08/05
  • 1st ionization energy added
    • update 2016/08/05 On the z-axis are:
  • electronegativity
  • atomic radius
  • density
  • year of discovery
  • boiling point
  • melting point
  • abundance in earth surface (logarithmic)
    • All of them are printable. Special version for dual colour printers placed here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1539966

Bulider dual feed, CEL Robox, Ultimaker original+

No

No

0.2

20%

comments.text: These are wonderful! I used the OpenSCAD file to make one for ionic radius for my school's chemistry teacher. THANK YOU so much for posting!
comments.author: jmelaragno

comments.text: How much effort willt it cost to create a version of your table showing the ionization potential?
comments.author: daktylus

comments.text: It's quite easy, i must just find values of ionisation potential for all of the elements. Have you idea where?
comments.author: daktylus

comments.text: The NIST provides a very good database on atomic properties. Go to: http://physics.nist.gov/PhysRefData/ASD/ionEnergy.html , search for "H - Ds I", and you will get a complete list of the latest values. If you want to minimize the list, you may uncheck everything in the "output data" field, except "Atomic number" and "element name". You might also switch of the field for "Bibliographic references:"Currently, the ionization energy is only determined for elements up to element 108, Hs. The "I" indicates the first ionization energy, meaning the ionization energy for the neutral atom, which we are searching for.
comments.author: Lumec

comments.text:
Great!!!
This database is exactly what I need. Your table is prepared for printing :D Thank you.
comments.author: daktylus

comments.text: Awesome. Thank you so much for the quick response. Printing it right now, this will take some time ;-) I'll poste a picture when finished.

comments.text: thank you alot! love the fact that the numbers are printable!

comments.text: How big do you think? It's completly programmed in OpenSCAD, so you can scale it up as you want!

comments.text: well i use simplyfy 3d to print it. and now i'm learning to use meshmixer to cut the stl file into pieces. Normally to design things i use inventor. So i have no experience with the other program.
comments.author: Lumec

comments.text:
That's a great idea!
Thanks a lot!!
comments.author: MoskWIN

comments.text: Hi Lumec!   I haven't checked the thingiverse for a long time, and I just noticed that you remixed the periodic tables I put up a couple of years ago -- way to go.  It looks like you even took the time to wade through my excel files and create your own openscad code -- I don't think anyone but you and I (and maybe knape in sweden) bothered to look at how the code is generated!  I have a question -- how are you using these 3D periodic tables?  (I use them myself with my high school students.)
comments.author: Tolle

comments.text:
Hi Tolle!
Your idea of making 3D periodic tables is brilliant! I tryed to print your tables, but lot of problems with symbols occured. Your code was to complicated for me to rewrite it, so i borrowed the idea of 3D periodic tables and made entirely code de novo.
Files published on this page are a bit out dated, last few weeks I was working on double colored tables (models for dual nozzle printers).
I added openscad and excel file to files. The idea is simple - You open excel file, changes data in column with data and entirely table copy&paste on the end of openscad document and render. Module prvek (translated - element) generates block with text.
You can modify multiplyer of element block height.
comments.author: Tolle

author: velzey

title: M2 Single Extruder for M2 and E3D

description.text:
This is my latest extruder design for my M2. This time I designed it for the E3D V6 hotend. I wanted the ability to use the continuous PTFE tube from the drive gear to the hotzone of the E3D. I am hoping this helps me print flexible filament better.
I did not like the idea of bolting the e3d in from the bottom so I designed this split arrangement.
The benefit I see in this design is that; The hotend is fixed relative to the gantry and does not rotate or shift; you can feed and remove the filament very easily; it has the most continuous support of the filament I have seen is a direct drive; it is easy to clear jams if they occur.
I am still thinking of better ways for a the tensioning system. It works now but you have to have a feel for how tight you need it and there is variability each time you redo it.
I would love to hear what people think of this design. This is a direct knock off of my dual design. I have not printed this version but all the geometry is the same except the part cooler so I do not foreseen any problems. Here is a video that goes over some details of the dual version.
https://youtu.be/qAHeEA26nSM
Here is the dual version
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:824403

The bearings are the standard size that came with the machine. The bolts that hold the bearing are 5x18 and I used a regular nut with no washers. The two bolts that lock the stepper in place are 4x whatever fits, a 18mm should work. Make sure to replace the x axis end switch stop or the extruder will run into the left side.

comments.text: Now that you have had time to use it for a while, how do you like it? Still using it?
comments.author: dintid

comments.text: looks like a super neat design! I'm having problems getting the fan shroud to slice well in simplify3d - at .3mm layer height with a .4mm nozzle it barely prints any of it, and at .1mm it still has some noticeable gaps in the middle of the print, where the tubes branch off. What settings did you use to print yours? Can you upload a slightly thicker version?
comments.author: rsheldiii

comments.text: I just uploaded a version of the part cooler that has walls almost twice as thick as the other version. I have not printed it yet. Let me know if that works for you. Thanks
comments.author: rsheldiii

comments.text: Awesome, thank you! I got the single walled version to print with a few gaps, but I'm going to print the new version once I finish the other parts and fit everything on. I'll let you know how it goes

Hi, I am glad you like it. I just uploaded a factory file for s3d that is what I just used to print one out in PLA. You will need to make the changes needed if printing in another material. It prints ok for me, there are a few weak/thin spots but it will funnel air which is what is important.
I will look at making a thicker version. My windows operating system was corrupted and I just got it working again so it will be a bit.

author: getitfixed

description.text:
This is the bowden drive for my dual e3d hotend design found here.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:824403 There are 2 versions of the part. The 1b1 version is still designed for the tube holders that came with my e3d hot ends bowden kit. They are pass through 10 mm thread types. Which means that the tubing can go all the way through the holder. I put stops in the passage that will prevent the tubing from being sucked back into the extruder gear when it retracts during printing. The larger 10mm threads of these connectors are almost to big. The 1c version is designed for some air pneumatic 5mm thread Dia 4mm hole brass quick connectors that I got off ebay. These are what I am using now with success. Update #1
I was having some issues when using retraction and thought it was because the geometry of how the gear lines up with the bearing. I made a few modification to the geometry and also reduced some of the plastic needed by creating a few voids which have so far not had any adverse affect on the extruder. I later figured out that I was running the temperature in the hot end too low which was causing most of my problems. I decided to upload this new version anyways because of the material reduction. It uses the 5mm brass fitting listed above. It is the 1d version.

comments.text:
What gear are you using - the small Wheel that bite into the filament? Maybe a diameter?
Asking as I'm considering remixing it to a non-geared nema, but I would like to use an MK8 for it.
comments.author: dintid

comments.text: It is the gear and stepper that came with my M2 from Makergear so I do not have a part number for it other than to say you could get more from them. The gear is 12mm in diameter on a 8mm shaft and is 12mm long if that helps.
comments.author: dintid

comments.text:
Ohh, that is just way off from what I have. But really nice to know. Should be possible to reposition the motor accordingly.
You are using 3mm filament?
It is your sliding mechanism and feeding without that grinder near the material that really appeals to me :)
comments.author: Xezerk

comments.text: I should have probably mentioned that in the description. These are designed for 1.75 mm filament. I will change it in a bit to reflect that.
comments.author: dintid

comments.text: Ok, thanks. Just thought the bowden(s) looking rather thick - I'm using 1.75 as well.

This is a fully 3d printable mechanical tally counter thing. The button function isn't perfect but the numbers scroll up fine. Not too hard to print it but you may need to file down parts to get nice gear meshing. Short Video I should note that the stl's I uploaded here are a little different than what I printed but should still work.

The intention is to have the button increment one digit at a time and have the knob, when pressed turn the numbers either way. The knob works great but the button needs some work.  
You need to print TWO carry gears. One of everything else.  
The three number wheels need some sort of support and maybe the case and cap as well.  
The button spring part may not print exactly as it the stl looks. It's a mesh problem but it's probably better the way it is.  
I have fixed the jogKnob file as of 7/26/15. Some slicers had sliced it as a solid piece.

comments.text: very cool printing now, the fun part will be to get it put together

comments.text: Cool!

comments.text: Hey ho,

comments.text: Hey there, nice work getting the parts printed. Unfortunately my original design included a part that didn't end up working when I printed it. As a result it kind of has the problems you described. Mine is the same. I was planning on trying to fix it but unfortunately just never had time.
comments.author: Fresh

comments.text: That worked great! I do have a question about the carry gears because they don't fit on the smaller tube thing. Is that suppose to be like that?
comments.author: smiley424

comments.text: They "should" fit on that smaller pin but if it prints a little rough you may have to help it a little. The one I made had the same issue. I would try carefully scraping off any imperfections on the smaller tube. I just used a file and a screw driver for that. I would also make sure the inside of the carry gear is really smooth. You could try wrapping some sandpaper around a pencil and working the inside of that gear. If you give that stuff a try and still don't think they'll fit, let me know and ill try to make the hole through the gears a little larger.
comments.author: smiley424

comments.text: when I went to load the jog knob into cura, it came out as a solid piece instead of having that hole in the middle, what's up with that?
comments.author: smiley424

comments.text: Hey, sorry about that. I originally sliced mine with slic3r and it seemed to work alright for me. I just tried it in Cura and it seemed to load alright but the when it sliced it the gcode was solid just like you said. I did fix it though and seems to work now in Cura so try re-downloading that piece. Let me know if there are any other issues.

description.text:
This is an illustration model of Archimedes' screw.
"Archimedes' screw, also called the Archimedean screw or screwpump, is a machine historically used for transferring water from a low-lying body of water into irrigation ditches. Water is pumped by turning a screw-shaped surface inside a hollow pipe."
Today is still used as a pump, in its original form in Egypt, and how small electric hydro generator in some engineering applications. this text above are a extract of the Wikipedia:
wiki article: Archimedes' screw Caution this model is very dangerous for children under 8 years, see intructions News
Version: V1.001 - 05/13/2015 - Corrected interference of the screw with the support. Versions V1_001. uploaded. source of data: Rorres, Chris: "The turn of the Screw: Optimum design of an Archimedes Screw", ASCE Journal of Hydraulic Engineering, Volume 126, Number 1, Jan.2000, pp. 72–80.

Archimedes screw Instructions Warning: This scaled model is not a toy, it is inappropriate for children, the parts are small and fragile, very easy to be broken and can cause fatal injuries if aspirated by children. Please look into
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toy_safety
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Home_Safety_Council Use glue to attach the handle crank
The ideal rotation is very slow, only 20 to 50 rpm

description.text: SD Card holder

Amano time recorder key
real working tested

My spice rack couldn't hold all of my spices, so I decided to make my own.
This file will generate a cut pattern for a laser cutter which will assemble into a spice rack. It was designed with 1/4" material in mind but it will adjust itself reasonably well if you use something else.
eps file parameters [at top of file]
-------------------------------------
material_thickness: how thick your input material is [matters for connections]
num_sides: the number of side pieces to render
num_beams: the number of beams to render
num_bottles_per_shelf: the number of bottles to fit on each shelf
num_shelves_high: the number of rows the spice rack will have

bottle_height: the height of your largest bottle plus a healthy margin
bottle_width: the width of your largest bottle as it faces you plus a margin
bottle_depth: the depth of your largest bottle plus a healthy margin

rack_beam_width: how wide each beam should be
laser_beam_width: for fine adjustment in the cut holes [affects tightness]
cut out at least 2 sides and as many beams as needed to connect them. I used wood glue to ensure it all stays together.

Ball and socket system, upgraded with a quarter turn twist lock on each ball joint to greatly increase pullout strength. My idea is to create a ball and socket system that is not only 3d printable but extremly strong and will not pop apart easily. This would be suitable for things like an LED lamp arm or heavy duty alligator clip where you don't want the neck popping apart. My original project was posted on hackaday:
https://hackaday.io/project/5739-locking-ball-and-socket-gooseneck-system Update 5/17/15
New STL files posted on 5/17/15 - should work much better on printers with larger layer height / lower resolution

• I printed the parts with socket up, this minimizes supports that are placed inside the socket, easier to remove from the ball.
  • I printed with a layer resolution of .01" or .25mm. For larger layers you should be fine, if you have any issues post them in the comments.
  • Use a fairly dense infill if you want these to be nice and strong. The intent is for this to make a fairly heavy duty gooseneck arm.

• Place nut over ball joint first before snapping socket onto ball.
  • Snap socket onto ball, requires moderate amount of force.
  • Slide nut onto socket, take care to align the locking features.
  • Twist quarter turn to lock in place. Small hex flats are 10mm, large hex flats on the twist-lock nut are 19mm.
  • Repeat for additional joints.

description.text:
It's hard to print the Snowden glasses small on an FDM printer.
However, it's easier when printing the halves separately. See the instructions for instructions on how to hack your gcode to get the side pieces right. Update
Uploaded example .gcode files (Ultimaker flavour, 2.85mm filament).

The side pieces can be a problem.
My solution is to have the printer make them with a straight vertical move (instead of stacked circles that most slicers will produce).
Here's how (tested with Cura 15.02.1): After slicing, edit the gcode.
  • Identify the start and end points of the side piece.
    ** Delete the gcode between those.
  • Also remove any gcode that leads to x/y movement after the side piece end point, for example homing (G28).
    • Depending on your printers characteristics (especially regarding oozing), you may also have to try the following iteratively:
  • increase the z-height of the end point
  • add some extrusion to the move to the end point

description.text:
A door latch designed for easy printing. Scale up to use on small gates, or print as is for latching smaller things like a door for your 3D printer enclosure.  
Holes are left for screws to fix it in place, or when used as a small latch the plate can simply be glued on.  
Unlike a regular latch, there is no way to rotate it to secure it in the closed position. This was done to enable an easier print than trying to print the long thin cylinder that would require. The entire print should have minimal overhang, with large flat areas in contact with the bed for an easy print.

title: Galaxy S5 holder for 2007 2WD ford expedition (Replaces coin holder on dash)

description.text:
2WD expeditions from 2007 had a "coin holder" thingy on the dash near the steering wheel, where the 4WD switch would go on the 4WD version.  I removed the coin holder from my dash and replaced it with a 3D-printed phone holder.    This will likely fit other model year expeditions, but I've only tested it on a 2007.  
Note:  I made the base in separate pieces to be glued together so that it will be stronger.  Most parts seem to break along the boundary between layers, so I wanted to have the loading in the springy pieces to be "in plane" for the layers rather than separating them.  The clips have several different orientations, so there was not a single position that would accomplish that goal, and the rest of the part made more sense to print in the orientation shown.

The phone holder is built from 3 components, a mount base which fits the hole in the dash, little clips which allow the mount base to stay in place semi-permanently, and a phone holder on a stick which inserts into the mount base.  I glued the clips to the mount base before installation, but the phone holder was a tight press fit to the mount base and did not require glue to stay.  This might allow a simple upgrade in the future if I get a different phone or whatever.  
Note:  I made the base in separate pieces to be glued together so that it will be stronger.  Most parts seem to break along the boundary between layers, so I wanted to have the loading in the springy pieces to be "in plane" for the layers rather than separating them.  The clips have several different orientations, so there was not a single position that would accomplish that goal, and the rest of the part made more sense to print in the orientation shown.

comments.text: Howdy! Thanks for creating this! The 04-08 Ford F150's (and possibly other F-Series) trucks also utilize this coin holder and they do fit. I'd like to make some modifications to it for mounting different devices securely. Would you be opposed to uploading your CAD files from the coin mount?
comments.author: GWXerxes

comments.text: uploaded ... I believe I was using Pro-E WF4 at the time, but the files should also open in Creo 3 (which I'm using currently).  Let me know if you want me to try uploading something else.

description.text: This file is to be used for cutting the frame for the Post-e portable Laser Engraver. The dimensions are designed around fitting the frame atop a standard sized ATX PSU and should be cut from quarter-inch acrylic or comparable material for best results. The layers are labeled for both ETCH and CUT runs for a laser cutter, however the etch design can be whatever your imagination comes up with! Pieces have been arranged to allow most efficient cutting using a 12"x16" cutting bed. Feel free to rearrange the parts to meet your cutting bed specifications. (Model is still a work in progress) Original project can be found at: http://www.instructables.com/id/Pocket-laser-engraver/?ALLSTEPS

Laser cut or mill out pieces from whatever quarter-inch material you choose.  
assemble pieces to match the model shown in the .3dm file  
Glue bottom section and top section together separately. You want to be able to lift the top part of the housing off to place electronic parts.

This is a mounting plate for the Arduino Due. It is designed to fit on 20 mm extrusions. There are some additional holes, i. e. for mounting 40 mm fans or some other gizmos.
A RADDS on top fits without problems in tha base of a Kossel Mini (with 2020 extrusions). Of course this thing is not restricted for MKs. :-) Credits go to user mundsen (http://www.thingiverse.com/mundsen) for providing the STLs of the RADDS hardware. UPDATE:
Added two mounts for cooling fans for Arduino / RADDS. One of them is sized to fit a 40x40x10 mm fan under a 2020MK. The second one has the mounting holes / wind tunnel raised by 12 mm.

description.text: Clips onto your Phoenix frame, holds your VA1100 camera, and protects your delicate circular polarized antenna. Also gives your quad fangs! https://tinkercad.com/things/6qjNWDce3kP

• Insert the prongs into the front rounded hole of your Phoenix frame. It will take a bit of force, and the prongs will bend a bit. Don't worry; keep pushing until it locks into place.
  • Insert the spacer between the camera mount and the frame (top side). This tightens and secures the fit.
  • Push your camera down into the round clip until you hear a click.
  • Fly, you fools!

title: Customizable T-Slot Profile (based on 20 mm extrusion)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A tool to create customized T-slot profiles for product displays, experimenting, printer frames, etc.  
Allows you to change the length, outer dimensions (currently only square profiles), wall thickness, center hole diameter, and most importantly the slot configuration!  
Alternate profiles are in the works, possibly rounded corner pieces and fusing together square pieces to produce non-square profiles.. Post your requests or corrections.  
I haven't had a chance to print and experiment with parts created using this tool to find the optimum parameters for a standard 20 mm extrusion, but at the very least it allows tweaking to fit your vitamins/printer tolerances

description.text: That's not mine. The pin. I've never-- zoom Video: https://youtu.be/TaLe7PBcHz0

It's a great big beautiful tomorrow, and I'm an optimist! True story: Carousel of Progress is my favorite theme park ride of all time. Printing:
If it's too snug of a fit, scale up the top half (1952_pinfront) up by 1%. (I printed it at 101% on my Rep 2.) "Electronics":
Go to Target. Find a cheap "touch LED watch", probably in the children's clothing area. Pop out the innards and insert into your printed pin. (Specifically, this is the watch I sacrificed for a better tomorrow. http://amzn.to/1FjD1HM ) One day, I'll learn how to be a science adult and solder. One day.

author: komadojiro

title: DaVinci 1.0 Tilted 50mm Fan Clip-On Curved Front Duct with Support

description.text:
After using my previous duct (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:785491) I saw significant improvement on my PLA prints. However, I was still unsatisfied. I still saw occasional spots that could have been avoided with more air flow. Also, when I put my hand over the back side of the fan, I felt air coming out. That's when I decided to change the design a bit to maximize the airflow to the extruder.
  • I tilted the fan to point it more towards the right direction.
  • I curved the duct to better facilitate air direction.
    • Happy to say the result is significantly better than the previous duct. Like the previous, this is designed with supports in place. Just slice and print.

Mine was printed with 0.3mm layer thickness and 10% infill using ABS. No support was needed. Once printed, simply break off the supports. For the fan compartment, a sharp blade may facilitate in support removal since it's quite tight for fingers.  
I was having such great results printing PLA, I decided to print a new PLA version of this duct. It came out even better than the ABS. I hate to say this, but I might not buy any more ABS after this.   
Since someone had asked about my fan setup, I will include my response in the instructions.  
I have a 12v 50mm fan. If you open the back of the printer, you should see a 12v and a 5v connector. You should be able to tap into either depending on your fan without any problems. The fan should draw very little power. If you search around online, you should find several solutions. Some people soldered, but I tapped into my 12v using a pair of micro grabber clips, the type used for testing electronic boards. I ran my wires along with the original harness into the printing area, and up the extruder wire harness. You do have to be careful because some of the print head movements may cause wires to rub with the ceiling of the printer. Just make sure your wires are not rubbing.
I have also added a relay module controlled by OctoPrint. By default, the fan turns on when I start a print, and off when the print is complete or cancelled. Since I print primarily with PLA, this default behavior works well for me. For any other materials that I do not want the fan, I I can turn off the van manually via OctoPrint once the print has started.
For bonus points, you can add a relay module to control the venting fan. To do this, I used a single relay module powered by 5v and triggered by 3.3v. For the trigger, I tapped into the LED signal of the printer. You can find a 3-wire harness towards the top of the main board. All three wires are brown. It should be obvious. The first wire on the right gives a +3.3v when the LED turns on, and a -12v when it turns off. Now, my venting fan turn off automatically when the printer goes to sleep.

title: Kossel Mini Single and Dual Effectors (Kraken, J-Head. E3D-v6, UBIS)

description.text:
I've designed a few effectors for my Kossel Minimax (a Kossel Mini derrivative) to hold various hotends. Included is effectors that support:
  • Single & dual J-Head
  • Single & dual E3D-V6 and Lite6
  • E3D Kraken
  • Printrbot Ubis
    • The Ubis, E3D, and J-Head hotends have a standard Kossel Mini effector radius of 20mm. The Dual J-Head and E3D-v6 effector have an effector radius of 25mm. The Kraken effector has an effector radius of 30mm. apologies if any of the STLs need to be flipped over before printing.

All STL files should be ready to print.  
The J-Head will use a 1/8" bowden fitting, or drill out to whatever size you need.  
Make sure you update your firmware if you're changing effector sizes.  
The dual hotend has one extruder at Y+12mm and the other at Y-12mm (assuming you orient the effector so the nozzles along the Y axis)  
The kraken is centered with each hotend being +/- 10mm on both axes from the center of the effector.

title: Trash Can Clips - Save & Recycle your plastics!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
One of my favorite things about FDM printing is the recycling aspect, enabling users to use their failed prints/supports/brims again if they happen to have a filabot or similar contraption standing around.
I personally do not have a filabot nor will I have room for it in the foreseeable future, but I know of makerspaces who are thinking about adding one to their repertoire.
So, no matter how you will get your filament from your scraps, it's probably a good idea to sort it by material and color while you wait for a good quantity to build up! These clips are intended to label plastic bags at the top (I store all my bags in a drawer so I'd have to lift each one up to see its contents) as well as providing a pretty good seal against dust.

Prints without support when turned upside-down, but make sure to enable your cooling fans when it comes to bridging over the letters. 0.3 mm layer height should be sufficient unless you like your scraps to be extra pretty ;-)  
I use 3 liter plastic bags and found that the clips work best at 90 % scale for these, but any larger or paper bags will probably require the original size.

I Had a problem when using a PLA bushing for my new prusa x-carriage, i found that a PLA bushing seem no good to holding on a X Axis Rod and make it less gap btw them. So, i redegin a whole x-carriage by using a PTFE as a bearing and I also using a two side screw tensioner fit onto x-carriage, it works very fine for me to tightened X axis belt just by (un-tightened 2nos M3 belt clamps screw + turning screw tensioner as you want how x belt to be tighten). However, I notice that this design may be no suitable for whom who is using
a two supporting screw to holding a hot-end nozzle, due to the opening of this carriage is not to big. (What i'm using is PEEK sleeve inside with PEEK thermal barrier, So, i dont need that supporting screw.) BOM List.
  • PrusaXCarriagePTFEbearing RP x1
  • PrusaCarriageBeltClamp RP x1
  • 12mm or 12.5mm PTFE ROD with 8.2mm hole x2
  • 7mm dia screw tensioner x1
  • m3 nut x6
  • m4 nut x2
  • m3x20 x6
  • m3x12 x4

title: Tesla Valvular - Designed and patented in the 1920's

description.text: This is a no moving part one way valve. Best suited to high pressure pulsed gasses and liquids such as those produced by the Tesla turbines.

This was made on a DaVinci 1.0A. The part was placed diagonally to accommodate its length.
The print was 0.3mm and 30% solid. Using ABS.
It takes about 2 hours and used about 14m of filament.
A cover is required which can be transparent acrylic and needs to be secured/glued to the top to stop leaks.
Inlet and outlet pipes are required, these can be drilled in the recesses at either end and glued in place.

description.text: This is a remix of a current E3D Direct Drive.  This design was created to utilize some of the hardware directly from the extruder in the FolgerTech.

Because of the height added the z endstop will need to be changed due to lack of room. Attached is a bracket that bolts into the z axis motor mount. It will also require an attachment to the x axis motor mount to add a small screw for adjustment. Something similar to this. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:772295

comments.text: I have 623 and 626 bearings.. can someone help me understand what modifications I'd need to make to this?
comments.author: VanBot112

comments.text: The only bearing you "need" is the bearing that applies pressure to the filament on the idler.  This design has a grooved bearing.  You will have to re-size the channel the bearing rests in the idler.  Then you will have to adjust all the parts that have the filament pass through.  You want to make sure that the filament passes straight through without any kinks or bends from misalignment.  Then you will have to adjust the part that clamps onto the extruder because it will probably be out of alignment as well.  So basically a complete redesign.  If you have the folgertech printer, you should still have the grooved bearing.  If you do not then you might want to look at the design this was remixed from.
comments.author: VanBot112

description.text:
If you're looking at this, you probably really want this version that has better access for cleaning the hobb and also a guide for the filament integrated with the idler:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17030 If you are interested in the stages of development, read on for the details of this version: This is an update to my Accessible Wade's Extruder. The idler is now hinged using an M3 screw.
I have also added support for the central part of the 608 idler so that there is no need to use washers to space the bearing away from the plastic. I have been using this design for a while now and love it. Changing filament is a simple as compressing the spring then whipping out the old filament and poking the new one in. UPDATE: 6 Aug 2011 - Add arcol (cory75 thing:10532) and wildseyed hotend mount options. Im not overly happy with the asymmetry of the arcol option.

comments.text: I'm using the MakerFarm version of this.  What I noticed is as the motor tries to extrude, the large gear turns, turning its inset nut with it.  This of course turns it clockwise along its axis, toward the extruder side, subtly tightening the hobbed bolt against its washer/bearing on the other side.  The hobbed bolt eventually gets shoved up against the washer/bearing so tightly that the motor can't extrude.  Is there any workaround for this?  Has anyone experienced this?
comments.author: shiggity

comments.text: Lock a second nut against the first to prevent if from tightening itself.
comments.author: shiggity

comments.text: I appreciate the advice, I did try locking an outer nut against it but figured it loosened since in practice the extruder locked up, and in theory during forward rotation the large gear would want to break away from it by moving toward the extruder.  It'd be difficult to tighten an inner nut against it given the narrow space.  Maybe I have a different problem, but I can't imagine why else it would extrude normally for several minutes and then become slower and then refuse to move at all?

A script written in Python (version 2.7) for reading as ASCII PGM file, and then writing an STL "surface" from it.  
After playing with the PGM to OpenSCAD surface script, I was disappointed to find that OpenSCAD would not create the STL files for images larger than about 200 pixels square. So, I did what any hack programmer would do, I wrote my own script to bypass OpenSCAD and go straight to an STL file! Voila!

You need to have an installation of Python version 2.7 (it will probably fail to run on version 2.6, sorry), with Tkinter. Use a photo editor like IrfanView or ImageMagick to convert a photo to PGM format, but make sure it is in ASCII format! The STL file will be a mirror image of the PGM. You can plan accordingly. Set the "relief" value (1 to 5) depending on your purpose for the STL file. A value of 5 gives "high" relief, but might be too high for some purposes. Caveat: STL files will be LARGE! A photo that is 253px by 313px is processed into a 7.6MB STL file with 79,000 vertices and 157,000 faces! I've successfully created an STL of 158MB with over 1.5M faces, but it takes a long time to convert. MeshLab reads the output files well. I have not yet printed a STL file made with this utility. I will try to post a picture of my first success with that.

comments.text: sawdusty,
comments.author: ibyte8bits

comments.text: The script works great creating the surface but it is really large. I modified the program to scale it properly. Unfortunately the output is not a solid. It is only one side of a solid so it can't be printed. I don't know enough about mesh creation to fix this. If you can revisit the script and have it generate a bottom and sides this will work perfect.
comments.author: mikeq

comments.text: The script intentionally creates only a "surface" as the description says. I have no way to predict how people will use the resulting STL file so I cannot determine what a resulting solid should be like. It is better to think of the STL created by this script as an intermediate step rather than the final product that is "ready to print". You can take the surface and manipulate it in other STL programs like MeshLab or even Blender and create a solid using boolean operations or similar tools to add or subtract the surface from other objects. If the script created a solid this would be much more difficult. Hope this helps.

This thing is an idler adjuster for a SeeMeCNC Rostock Max v2.  
Note: This may fit the v1 and Orion printers.  
This adjuster makes tightening the belts on the Rostock Max v2 easier. It is designed to allow you to tighten the belts without putting pressure on the pulley or mangling the Melamine using small, improvised pry bars. It also helps to keep the pulley aligned (perpendicular to belt).  
If you're like me and do not want to tighten your idler bolts too tight, the adjuster allows you to lightly tighten the bolts without the idler slipping.  
OTOH, if you have over tightened the idler pulleys and crushed the Melamine thereby rendering future adjustments problematic, this adjuster can solve the problem because it provides a rest for the bolt. Provided you don't over tighten it and crush the plastic. See a pattern here? Stop it! ;)

Vitamins (6) M4 nuts
(3) M4 nuts
(3) M4x35 or M4x40 bolts
(3) #6 x 2-1/2" bolts (replaces the idler bolts) Note: 3" bolts will work too but will stick out a bit
(6) #6 fender washers Note: You can substitute SAE hardware if you'd like but be sure to make the change in the .scad file. Instructions 1) Print (3) sets of adjuster and plate with 0.2mm layers and 40% infill Note: you can use coarser layers, but you may need to sand or smooth out the angled slots to allow the idler bolt to slide freely. The notches associated with higher layer heights can make the adjuster harder to use. 2) Remove your filament, spool, and spool arm (not the spool tower).
3) Carefully remove the Acrylic panels from the top section. A piece of blue painters' tape can help grip the panel. Go slow!
4) Remove the plastic bolts (3) on top of each axis.
5) Lift off the top panel careful not to damage the tabs on the side panels.
6) Remove the bolts from all idler pulleys. For each tower, do: 7) Insert (1) M4 nut in each adjuster body (inside face).
8) Thread a M4 nut on each M4 bolt (all the way down)
9) Place a M4 washer over the bolt
10) Thread the bolt through the adjuster body and through the nut.
11) Place the adjuster over the tower (notches down) and then place the bar in place. Be sure your wiring is routed away from the adjuster - that's what the cutouts are for! The bar should be positioned with the angled side against the tower so that the bar sits flush and the face is vertical.
12) Place a #6 washer on the #6 bolt and thread it through the adjuster and idler. You may need to wiggle things to get it line up.
13) Install another #6 washer and the #6 Nylock nut but don't tighten yet.
14) Tighten the M4 bolt on the adjuster. This pulls the adjuster toward the center thereby tightening the belt. Lifting the idler pulley with your fingers will help speed the process.
15) When the belt is tight, use the M4 nut to clamp the position of the adjuster bolt and lightly tighten the idler bolt.
16) Repeat (7)-(15) for each tower.
17) Replace the top and side panels
18) Replace the (3) plastic bolts.
19) Replace the Acrylic panels.
20) Replace your spool arm and reload your filament.

title: CNC Arduino / Grbl Shield stack w/ 60mm fan

description.text:
This is an Arduino Uno + Grbl Shield + Stepper Driver + 60mm fan stack.   
I have remixed/customized my earlier design for an Arduino Mega 2560 slide-in holder and also the MOAB fan bracket for this setup which can be used to drive a small CNC such as the Shapeoko.  
The 60mm fan provides the required airflow to run the stepper drivers at or near their maximum current rating (theoretically up to 2.5A for the DRV8825 stepper drivers, but realistically around 2A) without fear of thermal shutdown.  
The OpenSCAD source code is provided so the thing can be further remixed. License is GPLV3.

Here shown printed in Green PLA with 35% infill.  
Note that the slide-in holder should be mounted vertically so that the Arduino Uno slides in from the top, with the USB connector facing down.  
The fan brackets require 4 x M3 16mm hex screws and nuts.  
The slide-in holder is designed for wood screws but can also be used with M5 screws.

title: Tricopter V3 Platform for a PixHawk

description.text: With the new Tricopter v3 having a cut-out to route your wires up to the top of the plate you need to get that controller board up off the surfaces in order to run the wires up. This is a simple platform that allows just that. You will have to drill some holes in your frame to allow for the screws but its not a big deal. I used M3 screws and they should fit nice and tight. If you want to be sure it will never ever ever come off back fill the holes with some super glue and bam. It's on there. buy a Tricopter v3 frame over at http://rcexplorer.se

you need 4 x 6mm m3 screws to complete this project. you will also need a small drill bit in order to make the holes in the frame for the m3 screws to go through.  
i mounted my Pixhawk with a folded over length of mounting tape.

title: Hinged Box With Latch, Somewhat Parametric and Printable In One Piece

description.text:
I searched the Thingiverse for a simple hinged box that was parametric and printed all in one piece. I couldn't find one. I did find some really neat parametric boxes and lids though. I used none of their OpenSCAD code for this.  
I've printed probably a dozen one piece boxes with hinge during my testing. I wanted a tight hinge that would reliably print and NOT fuse together. During my testing I experimented with different speeds, temps, and tolerance values in my SCAD files. The attached OpenSCAD files prints reliably on my printer. The resulting hinge is a bit loose but it reliably does not fuse. Changing the tolerance by .1 does make a much tighter hinge, but sometimes I could not break it free. YMMV.

You'll need a fairly dialed in printer to do this. If your printer calibration is way off, you won't get a good hinge mechanism. I printed this one with: Layer Height: .15
Infill: 100%
First Layer Speed: 40mm/s
Speed: 80mm/s
Shells: 2 I'm using MakerWare. I used to think it was crap but I'm getting really good results with recent versions. In MakerWare: feedDiameter: 1.77 (caliper measured 1.75mm filament)
feedstockMultiplier: 0.87
retractDistance: 1.0
retractRate: 20.0
restartExtraDistance: 0.0 If your filament delivery system is not tuned up, you'll probably get a hinge that's fused together and will not fold. The OpenScad file is not idiot-proof. You have to supply a width, depth and height for the box. These are the outside dimensions make sure you add in the wall thickness if you need these to mean inside dimensions of the box. Once you change the depth value, you'll probably need to manually adjust the size of the hinge fingers so you get a reasonable distribution of the fingers and you don't get a missing finger or a really thin finger that won't print, or would be very weak. Also, do not scale this down and try and print it. The hinge will be fused together.

author: anewsome

description.text:
Pinza para cargar tu Xperia Z sin tener que abrir la tapa USB.
Como si estuviera en el dock station.
Necesitarás un cable USB, 2 pines (los puedes hacer con cualquier conector o alambre), un muelle de 7mm de diámetro máximo y 25mm de largo (seguro que tienes algún bolígrafo), y las piezas impresas.

Imprime las piezas.
Coloca el muelle en la pieza macho. Sujeta el muelle comprimido, con un destornillador metiendo éste por el agujero.
Une la pieza macho con la hembra sin soltar el muelle. Cuando estén unidas saca el destornillador y comprueba que funciona.
Ahora coloca los dos pines que habrás soldado a los cables rojo y negro del USB. El del cable rojo (+) es el pin que tiene que ir a la parte de arriba del teléfono. El del cable negro (-) es el pin de abajo.
Pega el cable a la pieza macho para evitar que se desuelde y coloca la tapa. (Yo eché un pegote de silicona térmica y quedó todo sujeto).
Si quieres el recoge cables, es otra de mis cosas.
Desconozco que pasaría si los cables se juntan por una mala soldadura o un tirón pero supongo que algo se romperá.

title: S Shape Kitchen and Cooking tools Holder

description.text: This little tool is a replacement for the typical iron S-Shaped rod, which is used in the kitchen to hold things in a iron/aluminium/... bar. Just put the part with the rounded ball, the hook with a "ball" (The narrow one) in to the iron bar, and then use the wide hook to hold things. To get this thing working look at instructions

• Height: 10 mm
  • Holder Hook Radius: 8 mm
  • Attatch Hook Radius: 6 mm
  • Lenght: 47 mm Aprox.

description.header: In order to get this working you need to measure your iron bar!
description.text:
Just measure the iron bar where you want to get the things being hooked and make you sure that the bar is not bigger than 5.9 - 6 mm or else the hook will not fit.
And; The part where the tools are hooked is the smooth, thin part with the biggest radius, but the other side, the one with the 'ball' or 'cylinder' or whatever do you want to call it is the side that goes with the bar.

I've extended my earlier parametric lamp shade to actually fit a nice old lamp where the cloche was broken. In particular, the stand notch parameter allows the bottom to be inward rounded so it can be fixed with screws or "clicked" into something. The parameters I've used are shown in the gallery. I've put some more detail on how I made it into Instructions.
I've calculated this one with quality setting "2" (which took 100s on Chrome on a newer laptop). Link is still http://beta.gigmade.com/2015/04/beautiful-curves/ Update: very high resolution now available.

Download customized STL at
http://beta.gigmade.com/2015/04/beautiful-curves/ The two "piriform height constant" results in an object where the rounded shapes length is roughly double the value you enter, in mm.
There's a vertical and horizontal scale for the overall end thing in case you want to adjust the end result without changing other values. Printing
This is a thing you have to print in "vase-mode" and no bottom wall.
In Ultimakers "cura" slicer e.g., the setting to check is called "spiralize outer contour", and uncheck "solid infill bottom". Then it should work. As you might see, I've used an Ultimaker with a custom fan (google "tapir shroud"), but I don't think it this made a big difference. Instead, to be on the safe side I've gone down to ridiculously low speed at the place where there is a large outward angle - I think it might have been between 15-20mm/s (at 210°C temp PLA). I'm sure it could work faster but I just didn't want to risk it. Print took about 8-9 hours with these settings. The light it gives is really nice but be careful: at least with PLA you should definitely use a LED light, with a regular 40W bulb the thing is going to slowly deform.

title: Needle file handle for 3mm needle file.

description.text:
In early days of 3d printing I sanded my prints a lot.
This is a must have tool. I know there are many versions, but I wanted 3mm needle file to fit in http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:216145.
So I decided to create this thing from the ground.
Every hole is slightly oversized to match even poor quality printing, but still works.

No supports needed.
For a good fast print I suggest to turn the cooling fan on, even for abs print. Then you will be able to print this in 7sec/layer or less timeout. Otherwise the edges may float due to the fast layer change.
You will need a 3m or 4m screw and nut to hold needle file in place.

author: bookmake

description.text:
Examples of the new drum feature of the pinion modules of version 6 of the clockwork library.
Allows for adding a drum to any gear or escapement wheel, and includes flanges to keep the string on the drum and out of the gear train.
Depth of the flanges is one half of the defined rim width, or one third of the drum height, whichever is smaller.

Invoke pinionDrum() normally, and the drum will now have flanges. 
Invoke pinionWheel() or pinionEscapementWheel() normally, and the spacer between the two gears will now be a flanged drum.

This project is ongoing. Updates will be listed below, with the most recent at the top. UPDATE 2: We've added an ultrasonic sensor adapter for the rail system. Be sure to carefully fit the sensor in the first few times. Afterwards, it should slide in perfectly. UPDATE 1: We've improved the body and main wheels. We've also added rails on top to add on anything you can think of. We're using the "shield" component to hold a breadboard. You could easily modify it into a Raspberry Pi case or other enclosure to expand this platform. We've designed and built this 3D printed Arduino driven robot to use as a platform for projects and for teaching basic robotics, 3D design, and Arduino programming in workshops. This is the second attempt. The first used tank tracks but was VERY complicated! This one is simple and has worked well despite a few bugs. It is still at thing in progress. We will be making several of these so as improvements are made, we will upload them here. Read more here: http://www.makerzoo.co/the-making-of-a-robot-kit/ Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FIg3g75xPOo

Building this robot. 3D Printing: We printed this out on the lowest possible resolution on a MakerBot Replicator 2. We used rafts and supports but would recommend only printing the body with supports and everything else without them in a separate print. If you have the time, of course feel free to use better resolution!

  • You will need 2 9g micro servos converted to continuous rotation. We have a tutorial here ( http://www.makerzoo.co/converting-servos-for-continuous-rotation/ ).

  • You will also need some 3mm bolts and nuts of various lengths. Also, some small rubber bands could be glued into the groove on the main wheels and also the caster wheels.

  • We only had long 3mm bolts so we used a rotary tool and a cutting wheel to cut them off. PLEASE USE SAFETY GOGGLES WHEN DOING THIS!

  • The main wheels now fit much better than previous versions. All you need is the screws that come with your micro servo to secure the wheel to the servo armature.
    • Read more here: http://www.makerzoo.co/the-making-of-a-robot-kit/
